• Starters
  • TeacherInstructions
      • Turn It On, Turn It Off!

      Give student groups 90 seconds to name as many objects they know that turn on and off. One student in each group will write on paper or poster board while the others call out items that can be added to the list. Reflect on whether they all produce the same types of energy.

      Could We Live Without It?

      Bring items into the classroom, such as a remote control, light bulb, DVD case, or other items related to electrical or light energy. Have each group work with one item. Groups describe five ways how their lives are made easier or more fun with the selected item and then vote whether they could “live” without it.

      Heat to the Rescue!

      Ask students what they know about heat energy. Responses can include cooking food, staying warm in winter, or melting chocolate for smores. Have each group create a “Heat Superhero” to illustrate an example of heat energy used to make our lives better or more comfortable. This may take the form of a furnace with a cape, a mug of hot liquid with a mask, or any other personified examples students think of.
